summary.p: He thinks it would be better if [Jakob Fehr] stayed in Bischofszell out of consideration for his family; however, perhaps Fehr will decide differently after receiving the letter from Theodor [Bibliander]. He hopes that [Konrad Zwick] will accept the invitation [to Urdorf], and sends greetings.

div.p: What you write about the transfer to Bischofszell, dearest Bullinger, does not please me. For I hear that the situation of that good man has already begun to improve. Therefore, it would be very difficult for such a good man to travel such a distance and bear the burden of his family. Moreover, he has a wife and children, as I understand from good friends, such that it would be more prudent for him to stay with his own. But I wish this to be written only to you. Perhaps he will respond differently upon receiving Theodor's letter. May the Lord's will be done, not ours.

Farewell; for I have nothing else to write. I am glad to hear that the brother has been called to you; I hope he will not be lacking in such a sincere fellowship. Again, farewell with your mother, wife, children, and your entire household.
To the distinguished man, Heinrich Bullinger, pastor of the church in Zurich, his esteemed lord and brother. Zurich.
